title: Will more than 6,000 new battery electric vehicles be registered in Germany in the third quarter of 2016?
preds: A local Mitsubishi dealer estimated that they sell eight normal cars and then a hybrid; pure battery cars much much less. Subsidy applications are reported to be approx 3000 nationwide.
2016 is not a great year for electric vehicles.
Misleading question...Germany has 25K in electric cars already registered. New registrations defined how?
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
August data shows still very weak interest.

Fully electric vehicles have lately sold <1,000 units per month in Germany. Sales in July were reported at 915 units, which gives an estimated 2,745 fully EV cars sold in the 3rd quarter of the year, more than 2x lower than necessary to meet the 6,000 car goal.
I hope this forecast compensates my error with the Emmy's
According to the general news and GJP consensus, and time decay.
Seems my former rational had very different number than your sources. Checking some more sources it would be a huge increase in sales, and seems unlikely.
too expensive, no incentive, too few chargin stations

The number of electric cars sold as be growing substantially, last here there was a total of almost 5500 units sold in the same trimester, growing this to 6000 is a smalls step, and the german goverment just aunched new incentives to buy electric cars in May.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
There have been a few recent informative comments. Dropping to 1% from 9%.
Half year data far from promising.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

July was 785; 
3rd quarter so far : 1680
I think it is unlikely to have 4320 e-vehicles registered in September. => 0%

Upto about 1680 at end of August so highly unlikely, but Mirai sales in US (large corporate, government puchase still a possibility)

Less likely with lower gasoline prices.
I do not believe that market will grow faster than maybe some 3000 cars despite being incentivized.

Comment from @ChristophPiller; Going to 1as trying to stop being too definitive in my forcasts!!
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/298091

I am living and working in the automotive sector in Germany. The subsidy program has been poorly received by Germans. I think this is a cultural problem. For a German, an electric vehicle is not a satisfied car (Germans found Audi, Mercedes, Porsche, BMW, ...).
Therefore I see a minimum chance to reach 6,000 new registered battery vehicles.
Check back when they get the July numbers up.

785 for first month of third quarter (thanks to @ts2m for link), should mean the game is over, given registrations couldn't even beat June's 833, and August is a particularly poor month seasonally (http://www.tradingeconomics.com/germany/car-registrations)

Business plan to 6000 cars:
+ 1200 July (400 more than in June, or +50%)
+ 2000 August (800 more than the hypothetical July, +66%)
+ 2800 September (800 more than the hypothetical August, or +40%)
======
~ 6000

http://evobsession.com/bmw-i3-sales-rose-germany-following-electric-vehicle-subsidy-implementation/

Earlier I assumed young well-off engineering types of people at uni cities to be buyers: here, a girl talking about costs and vacations with a Renault, and the daily 100+ km commuting for three years.
Slow progres in the applications for the subsidy (only few hundred after more than one month). Slightly up from the crowd because I bet for last minute "bolw-out Sale".
With a decline in sales for may there was a sale increase in june. But i think most people who wanted to take advantage of this did so tight away.

Q2/2016: 2.025 units sold -> to meet 6.000 new units sales has to triple from Q2 to Q3 
Q3/2015 -> 2.722 -> to meet 6.000 new units sales has to increase with 120% from Q3/2015. There was no such increase since 2013 (Q3/2012 to Q3/2013).
Source: http://www.kba.de/DE/Statistik/Fahrzeuge/Neuzulassungen/MonatlicheNeuzulassungen/monatl_neuzulassungen_node.html
Remote chances...only 1622 vehicles sold in Q2...but the EV incentive program started in May will uplift sales but not to the extent of 6000
Enough offers in mIddle and lower car classes, enough role models in upper class
No recent news of car sales increasing.
Some recent numbers about the 'kaufprÃ¤mie': 936 requests so far (14 July),  625 for battery electric vehicles. Most requests (about 2/3) are from private persons, the rest mostly from companies.
From what I can tell the subsidy hasn't been approved yet and I have yet to see June registrations.
Slow growth and continuing low oil prices make this less likely.

Relying heavily on the information from @Rene, @praedico and @ts2m, as I am struggling to get the links, we have 833 registered in June (when the subsidies were in play even if you could not apply for them), which is nowhere near the run-rate required to get to 6,000. Even if you add the 1,000 reported orders for the new BMWi3, which was released earlier than my previous forecast expected, and assume no cannabilism of current run-rate registrations, as well as assuming delivery of all of them during Q2, you only get 3,500. So dropping forecast down to 6% (to account for a sudden surge in registrations, law of small numbers).
Upping this slightly based on Reuters BMW report
"4.357 reine Elektrofahrzeuge bewirkten im ersten Halbjahr einen Neuzulassungsanteil von 0,3 Prozent"

The population are being financially incentivized in a population already highly accepting of green issues, and already familiar with green vehicles, and further financial incentives already exist, added to which is the cache' of being a green citizen in German society.

http://www.bafa.de/bafa/de/presse/pressemitteilungen/2016/19_emob.html
It's a table for how many subsidy applications were submitted, by car brand/model. Would somebody with a better memory try to discern how many battery electric vehicles they are, the table includes all sorts of electric cars.

Reuter's reports 1,000 new German sales of the BMW i3 due to the EV discount
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-bmw-i-idUSKCN0ZQ0O7?il=0
Initial forecaster posts, do not seem to have identified much positive news on sales.  Low initial estimates may decline further as early responders tail off.
Hello Tesla, our favorite early adopter of superforecasting ... some news from Germany

Between last Saturday, when the website opened, and Monday, 266 rebate-requests were submitted. All new electric vehicles from 18 May 2016 on are eligible for the rebate. 266 is not an awful lot. 'Der groÃŸe Ansturm bleibt aus' (second link).

It looks like 604 for April, 588 for May, 833 for June. 2025 for Q2. 2332 for Q1. Not much difference from 2015. Last year saw only a 19% increase from Q2 to Q3. I realize there will be subsidies, but a 296% increase in registrations over Q2 would be required to reach 6000 registrations in Q3.
The count began few days ago, this months.

EV volumes in Germany have dropped the last couple months but can probably be attributed to the coming EV incentive program.  I'm forecasting a weak euro in the third Q...1.05 to 1.07 for Sept 2016, SP500 debt downgrade for EU debt, and negative social mood = decreased spending. maintaining 5%
Berlin (dpa) reports: Starting this weekend, applications for subsidies are going to be accepted (only cars bought after May 18th qualify).

Essentially the question is asking if EV sales will rise by 185% in Germany within a year.
To get a base rate, this report on the US concludes
http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy15osti/63263.pdf
According to this report "A $1,000 increase in tax credit value is associated with a 2% to 10% change in per-capita BEV registrations". This varied by model.
In the Netherlands the incentive structure is a bit more complicated but "In total for 2015, plug-in vehicle reached 43,300 units, +183% over 2014" 
http://cleantechnica.com/2016/03/07/ev-sales-22-of-car-sales-in-netherlands-in-december-2015/
Initial crude calculations that 6000 euro incentive would mean a possible 12 to 60% within a year in the US and 184% in NL. So 185% is a long shot but possible.  
There a few specific German factors:
- this looks like it comes off the tag price of the car so it is likely to have more of an effect than tax credit.
- new models from German manufacturers are coming on stream, the US example shows models have an effect on sales
- Range anxiety is less of an issue that in the US due to higher population density
- Germans aren't like the Dutch on cars - the land of BMW 7 series and no speed limits on many motorways won't be crazy for EV

Consensus has dropped quite a bit after my initial forecast of 20%.
I have no problems dropping to 15% on this question just to keep pace.
Down 5% on expectation mattresses will have more gold stashed under them after the Brexit vote.

Given the considerable barriers remaining to battery-electric vehicle adoption and the fact that the €4000 subsidy only defrays about 10% of the price of the domestic models* I somehow doubt the quarterly sales are going to triple this year.
Germans have an appetite for latest technology
German people more confident of that vebhicle
About 16k-20k annually considering continued growth trajectory. Growth is slowing slightly, thus 6k a 1/4 seems to ambitious.
Government subsidy likely to increase take-up. UK (similar size pop) electric car buying is running at around 2500 per month with no govt subsidy.
Even with the subsidy, it is hard for sales to pick up from around 2100 of the 1st quarter to the 6000 needed

The German public focuses on safety this fits into that cultural thinking IF the infrastructure can support it as well.   I give it more than 50% chance for the culture impact, but believe that the other types of impact - speed and access to power will matter as well.

Perhaps if the government actually does subsidize battery electric vehicles this could happen, but without that incentive, it appears unlikely to hit 6,000 in the third quarter. Also, there are now 4 German automakers developing electric vehicles, so many buyers may wait to see what Daimler, especially, comes out with, which won't be until 2017.

Last year 12400 electro vehicles were registered, and aroudn 3500 in the first 5 months of 2016. 
I'm assuming that petrol prices will stay at current low levels for most of 2016. 
I still need to understand whether Jul-Sep was in the last years typically is a stronger sales quarter than the first 2 quarters.
For now I give 6000 new registrations over Jul-Sep a low probability.
Slowdown in May, 3524 cumulatively from jan to May, inclusive; 2016-05 alone 588. Rate in April was 700+ per month. Source, KBA.

This March was actually lower year-over-year with last March. February was an impressive 72% over last year, but was still small and had fallen slightly last year over the year before. 6000 would be a more than 100% increase over last year, which seems unlikely unless gas prices skyrocket.

In Q3 of 2015, only 2.7k electric vehicles were registered. This would mean that YoY growth would have to be over 100%, which is unlikely. Also, growth in the current year has been relatively stagnant, although this could be because of consumers waiting for the launch of the subsidies.
Subsidies are always a good way to make things happen yet this will require greater than a year-on-year doubling of sales which remains a big ask.

It is too early for incentives in Germany to go into effect to see that big of an uptick in sales. Additionally, the EURO is actually much weaker relative to the JPY and USD since q3 of last year. I believe the uptick will take place in Q1 2017.

The Global EV Outlook 2016 study noted, "The year 2015 saw the global threshold of 1 million electric cars on the road exceeded, closing at 1.26 million [100 times more than in 2010]. This is a symbolic achievement highlighting significant efforts deployed jointly by governments and industry over the past ten years. In 2014, only about half of todayâ€™s electric car stock existed. In 2005, electric cars were still measured in hundreds."

It seems like the amount of ev cars sold between 1st quarter of 13 and 1st quarter of 14 has nearly doubled. This is the only consequtive period in the data provided below. Even if it is expected to double that number this year it becomes somewhere in the region of 4500-5000. Very unlikely to exceed 6000...

My initial numbers included plug-ins which is a grave error.  The total number of solely electric vehicles is much less.  It seems unlikely now that they will reach that number in purely electric cars. At this time, roughly 25,500 cars are electric in Germany out of an approximate 45M cars. 
http://www.dw.com/en/germany-to-boost-electric-car-incentives/a-19214176

Electric cars are being registered more frequently in each of the least three years, but also more frequently in the later months of those years.  With the incentives to purchase these cars in Germany it seems likely that EV registrations will continue to increase in the coming quarters.  A 45% increase in '15 to 16' registrations shows that, however the forecast is asking specifically for the 3rd quarter results. 3rd quarter registrations improved last year at a rate roughly around 52%. It is my outside view that it can improve at that rate again (given the incentives) and will put 3Q results at around 8,500 registrations.  However, the numbers of registrations thus far in '16 have not been promising, so we can't assume these numbers will continue to grow at the same rate.

Anyone know if German government cars are included or when the Government buy cars etc as if they spend 100 million quickly it will make a huge difference to target. "another €100 million (US$113 million) would go toward purchasing electric cars for federal government fleets " https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#Germany. Anyone know if these count? Are government cars "registered"?
The sales-numbers for electric vehicles April and May 2016:

Just have a look on the Webpage of the Kraftstoffbundesamt. Just in May 286931 new Cars and 0,2% electric cars. So just estimate 600 cars per month is far away of needed cars of 2000 per month even if expect exponential growth. If you include hybrid cars than the number will be reached in a month.
The statistic from 2003 to 2015 says no, because in 2015 the delta to 2014 was 4.000 vehicles only (for the full year 2015.  The boom is not strong enough.

Maximum quarterly sales (Q4-15): 4 978, i.e. +21% growth required on maximum market absorption
Q1-16 sales: 2 332, but in anticipation of incentive scheme
Similar scheme in Canada (5 000 USD) doubled the sales of mass priced EV (A)
=> revisit with April data
Steady growth through 2014, 2015 and the start of 2016. Larger sales towards the end of the year. Should comfortably exceed 6000 by 10-20%.

"another €100 million (US$113 million) would go toward purchasing electric cars for federal government fleets " https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#Germany.   Anyone know if these count? Are government cars "registered"? Any news if scheme has started?

Given current sales statistics: Q3-15, Q1-16, it's not gonna happen. Figure that there's gonna be marketing + promotions +ads following the introduction of new subsidy scheme, so then it might be possible. Total share was 0.3%, so marginal percentage increase makes the target.

- to clarify question I’m assuming it’s 6K EV sold/registered in Germany the 3Q2016 NOT cumulative
- Germany very eco-conscious +
- EV has very small market share currently 0.4% of German car market so plenty of room to increase +
- there is enough German auto manufacturers that make EV’s available so this won't be a limiting factor, shouldn’t be damaging to the German car industry (almost 25% of cars registered are German) +  Tesla is too expensive for this program
-German govt has stated goal of 1M vehicles on the road by 2020, to get there need growth to materially accelerate +
-Sweden is similarly eco conscious and introduced a similar incentive in 1Q12 which led to a 4x increase in unit sales so this is strong ++ The Norwegian example is not comparable because incentives there are much higher at 17K EUR 
-German subsidy is not that big in 4K EUR this is a negative but slightly higher for a pure electric vehicle (only 3K for hybrid) slight + so net this is a wash to slight negative IMO
-only question marks are: 
-why were German electric vehicle sales so weak in 1Q16 down 2% y/y after strong 100% y/y growth in 4Q15? I can only speculate that consumers anticipated this incentive being announced so there is some pent up demand so this is a +
-timing- incentive program starts in May and is first come first serve up to 400K cars in total which should last a few years but may have some impact on pulling in demand so slight +
- the May partial month EV registrations will give us an idea of the trajectory but the June full month number will give us clarity - 1200 is a good number for June IMO to get to 6K in 3Q16
The new Tesla is not out yet.
It will be close, but the pressure coming form the "failure" of German diesel technology to meet goals will put a premium on achieving goals for environmentally friendly cars.
My previous estimate of 13.5k can be seen here: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/237241

The subsidies were declared on April 28th 2016, buyers have been waiting for those subsidies, car sales in March 2016 were low to reflect that. 
The subsidy is also on a first come, first served basis.

1."The number of electric vehicles on roads around the globe nearly doubled in 2014-15 to well above one million, new analysis has revealed, with China alone adding more than 200,000 to its fleet for the year.

Following the links the Guardian says that in Norway in the few months preceding January 2014 around 1200 all-electric cars were being registered. (Some additional incentives such as free parking and no tolls were being offered.) The population of Norway is only 5 million compared to Germany's 80 million. Germany is already selling around 2700 all- electrics per month. Even though Norway is rather richer than Germany I'd expect that the famously green Germans ought to at least buy all-electric cars at a third of the Norwegian rate. That would mean sales of slightly over 6000 cars per month. (1200*1/3*80/5).
I don't think so in a country as Germany in which traditional car industry is very powerful

I believe the German government is pursuing this for many reasons (e.g., "dieselgate", environmental concerns from 40x pollution pumped in the air but those cars,  damage to German engineering ethos, etc.) and as such I believe they will push very hard to make sure there will be at least 6,000 registered vehicles. One of the tools in their arsenal is getting municipalities and government entities to make up any shortfalls.

New electric vehicle sales in Germany, the largest European car market, rose 79% to 23,481 last year. New electric vehicle sales in the United Kingdom, the second-largest European car market, rose 97% to 28,715 vehicles, while sales in France rose 83% to 22,867 vehicles.
======
The data I have so far.

there has been natural growth without the incentive each successive year from 2012 onward, a simple linear projection takes us to 3800 sales in Q3 2016, the incentive is generous. 31% of the unconventional market has been e-cars, government paying share of the incentive is 600,000 over 3 years, assume 31% market share is maintained at 4000 per car approx. 3877 e-cars per quarter are incentivised. Some buyers will have been buying e-cars anyway though - say 50% so 1900 additional e-cars in Q3.1900 plus 3800=5700 - sources of error are many - incentive is generous and might get some bigger uptake in 1st year, limit to how many cars can be supplied, a spike in demand may not be able to be accommodated at the factory. E-cars will have a limited appeal and conventional drivers are more likely to take the hybrid option - less change but similar incentive.

The automatic response would be no for a multitude of reasons. Germans love their luxury cars, companies own the vast majority of the expensive flot and there are very few German-made full-electric cars on the market which cover the needs of the customers. A minor price reduction will not cover their willingness to pay.
There is no electric vehicle charging infrastructure
German automotive engineering has been focusing on enhanced performance for EV, making their attraction and purchase more appealing.

http://www.best-selling-cars.com/electric/2016-germany-electric-hybrid-car-sales/ reveals the trend, though it says the sales of electric cars have slowed down in the first quarter of 2016, and reaching the figure of 6000 in the 3rd quarter alone may prove unlikely.
Germany is very proud of their car export economy they will buy the cars.

Certainly, the new subsidies of the German government will help - if not boost sales of electric vehicles. However, besides enthusiast citizens or people who like to show off with their new Tesla as beeing environmental friendly, rich and trendy , the battery technology has not yet reached the average German consumer. The battery technology still is not strong enough, nor user friendly. It would be, in case a battery had the size and weight of a book , clean, integrated in the dash board, standardized and emtpy ones could be exchanged at any filling station against a loaded one - against a fair fee. Today, small battery cars are rather used as second cars or city cars or for citizens with their job in a 10 mile distance (or retired ones). Germans who like to drive to Italy, Spain, France , etc. for vacation still depend on the engine driven car.  The enigine is one of the core competencies of German car industry, BMW even is called "Bavarian engine works" - the industry thus did and does not fully support battery cars, however takes the topic serios as newcomer car brands may replace traditional ones, in case they do not switch in the right time. 
In Germany more than 40% of energy production still comes from dirty burning fossile coal. Thus "battery cars" in Germany are probably the most "dirty cars" in terms of the environment! Only 100% non-fossile energy will make them green!
It is the wave of the future.   Also, Germany is a very big producer of autos, hence it is logical the Germans will be at the vanguard.
Data (if correct) talk about 23.000 BEV in Germany in 2015, without the new rebate scheme, so it's just more or less a matter of repeating the performance of last year.
Staying below consensus, mainly due to the still rather poor supporting infrastructure.
Historical sales & growth don't support. Incentive boost impact not assumed that strong, though, should check incentive size vs ave elec car price

I would guess third quarter sales of electric-only vehicles to be 3500-4000. The subsidy would need to have a big impact in order to propel sales above 6000. The first month we'll see the impact of the subsidy is June. I'll check back at that time.

BEV cars sold in Q3 15 2,722
BEV cars sold in Q1 16 2,332
Growth rate 2013-14: 40.8
Growth rate 2014-15: 45.1
Growth rate needed to sell 6,00 in Q3 120%

the subsidy should raise demand but that's still a lot of ground to make up in one quarter. I think the subsidy will raise demand for domestically made electrics and away from foreign substitutes, (IOW, a change in price along the demand curve, but not necessarily shift demand upward.
Adoption of new technology takes longer than intuition says.

This is my first day on Good Judgement ... so this is just an un-researched guess. Putting it at 75% because 6k doesn't seem like a lot of vehicles given the demand for Teslas. That's more than double last year though. Also, weird that "plug-in-vehicles will not count". I'm not entirely sure constitutes a "battery electric vehicle" if hybrids and plug-ins are not counted. Guess I'll have to research that!
there are 60 million people in germany and lets say the half of them wil have a car so 6000 of  30000000 is 1 of 5000 so that isnt that much
Down 10% to be closer to consensus.
my initial forecast was purposefully placed below consensus.  Consensus has changed... dropping secondary to the group drop.  following @mcmahonimal.
Down 20% to be closer to consensus. Thanks for great collection of data @mcmahonimal

1. Expected Q3 2016 total sales: 800,000. [A1]
2. Electric car (BEV) registrations 2015: 12,363 (0.39% of total). [A2]
3. Expected BEV registrations: 3090.75 (from 1 and 2 above)
4. ev-volumes is projecting an 80% increase in PEV sales if the subsidy goes into effect May 2016. Assume BEV is similar. [A3]
5. Expected BEV registrations: 5560 (from 3 and 4 above)

YOY Quarterly comparisons means 120% required change to meet the 6,000 BEV target whereas incentives apply May 2016 onwards and apply to Hybrids also. German total auto sales for 2015 grew approximately 4% YOY with no particular incentives and VW under the radar which may have suppressed a normalized growth cycle. Assuming auto sales in Germany grow @10% per year then BEV growth of 100%+ appears aggressively speculative. Starting with a conservative estimate, following monthly sales trends with latest incentive packages that can change my judgement

The sales ratios of battery-only to hybrids for 2015, Q1 of 2016, and both (2015+Q1 2016) are roughly:
2015:          1 to 2.72
2016 Q1:    1 to 4.55
Both:           1 to 2.99
(For your GJP enjoyment, no Google translator, only me, from original sources)

While not quite as confident, Uhjoebilly reasoning sounds plausible. Third quarter registrations in 2015 were 2,722, so the question is asking if a 2x doubling is possible, and given that €1 billion program, €600 million of which is going towards the new subsidy. This seems a very safe yes.
I think 6,000 in the 3rd quarter is too soon, although I am sure there will be significant growth through 2017.

This is a gut call. I Lived in Germany for a while.  Fuel is expensive...really expensive!  So are new cars.  So is electricity.  Everything is expensive.  Average income is about 3500 euro a month.  They have wind mills all over the place that I think are mostly for show.  Car Registrations in 3rd Q in Germany is expected to be 261493 compared to 1st Q 315921 (actual) and 2 Q 282228.  A 4 thousand euro discount from the German Gov for an EV car is good but its all the other stuff that is complicated.  Germany also has a fairly efficient public transit system!  There are only 2638 EV charging stations.  It makes more sense to buy a hybrid versus just EV  I'm going to come in low at 33% and wait for the official 2Q registration numbers.

https://ev-charging.com/at/en/catalog/index/de/0.

Napkin math/Fermi Estimation: €1 billion program, €600 million of which is going towards the new subsidy.
Trust has wained in traditional vehicles.  People will start to look at alternative cars thanks to the emissions scandal.
Start at just under 50%, revisit when new data is available.
Too soon for a surge of registrations. 3Q vacation months and eve of 2017 models argue for "later".

The government will decide this Wednesday (18 May 2016). There is quite a lot of opposition against the proposal - from their own 'scientific advisory council', among others - but it seems they will go ahead anyway and add some tax-deductions too.

Electric (battery-only) vehicles (at discounts of 4,000 euros) will be competing heavily with Hybrids (at discounts of 3,000 euros).  With ample fuel supplies and low prices, I don't see a logical aversion to hybrids.  There is too much downside risk in buying a Battery-only as compared to buying a Hybrid.
